sample.title: What Gold‚Äôs Rise (Really) Means for the World
sample.description:
Gold‚Äôs price per ounce surged past $4,000 this month, a record-breaking rally tied in part to eroding confidence in the US dollar. Uncertainty driven by Donald Trump‚Äôs trade war as well as questions about the independence of the Federal Reserve and America‚Äôs wavering economy have also played a part. Add to that heightened geopolitical tensions across the globe and you have a recipe for a mass flight to gold. And that‚Äôs exactly what central banks and investors have been doing. 

Now with China seeking to offer an alternative to American dominance, we look at what gold‚Äôs historic rise means for the global financial system. 

Sign up for the Economics Daily newsletter to discover what's driving the global economy and what it means for policy makers, businesses, investors and you.

sample.title: Why EVs Depreciate Faster Than Gas Cars
sample.description:
EV‚Äôs are cheaper to operate than a gas car, but their resale values are horrible. It‚Äôs a mix of factors - incentives, changing tech and limited appeal. It‚Äôs a problem for EV adoption, especially as automakers try to attract more mainstream buyers. Here‚Äôs why they can be more expensive to own than a gas car, and why that might change.

sample.title: Why younger Americans are saving money at such a high rate
sample.description:
As Americans live longer and worry about outlasting their money in retirement, a growing number are counting on one strategy for their future financial security: working longer.

Roughly 70% of U.S. workers who haven‚Äôt retired yet have considered pushing back their retirement date, according to a recent survey from F&G, an insurance company. Nearly half of the 2,000 adults surveyed said they‚Äôre afraid they won‚Äôt have enough money to retire.

sample.title: The $1 Trillion Tangled Web Of AI Deals Mapped Out
sample.description:
The pace and scale of artificial intelligence infrastructure deals lately has been staggering, with OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, alone racking up around one trillion dollars worth of AI deals this year. These interconnected investments between companies like Nvidia, Oracle, Broadcom, CoreWeave, Meta, Google, AMD, Microsoft and others have dramatically lifted the valuations of many of the companies involved and sent U.S. stock indexes soaring. But some experts are worried that this tangled web of deals is reminiscent of the dotcom bubble.

Produced by: Magdalena Petrova
Animation: Christina Locopo
Additional Reporting: Kif Lewsing, Ashley Capoot, Mackenzie Sigalos
Edited by: Erin Black
Senior Director of Video: Jeniece Pettitt
Additional Footage: Getty Images

sample.title: Why The AI Boom Might Be A Bubble?
sample.description:
Artificial intelligence is driving a wave of corporate investment unlike any in decades, with forecasts calling for $500 billion in global AI spending by 2026. Experts describe this as a "capex supercycle," but warn it may be propping up an otherwise fragile U.S. economy. If AI spending slows or fails to deliver on its promise, the consequences could ripple through markets, employment and economic growth.

2:11 What happens if AI spending slows?

sample.title: What the U.S. can learn from Canada's banking system
sample.description:
FDIC data shows that the U.S. has nearly 4,500 banks. Canada has only 79 banks, according to the Canadian Bankers Association.

However, America‚Äôs banking industry is consolidating. FDIC-insured banks in the U.S. are down by nearly half since 2005.

sample.description:

The president said Thursday that he and other ‚Äúhigh-level advisors‚Äù will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Budapest, Hungary, to discuss how to end the war. sample.title: Squawk Pod: Regional bank stress & Schwab‚Äôs record quarter - 10/17/25 | Audio Only
sample.description:
Bank stocks are tumbling as concerns about bad loans at regional banks have worried global investors. CNBC‚Äôs Leslie Picker reports on the selloff and what‚Äôs driving it. Charles Schwab CEO Rick Wurster discusses the health of the U.S. lending ecosystem and his own firm‚Äôs record quarter, including Gen Z appetite for retail investing and growing demand for alternative assets. CNBC‚Äôs Steve Liesman breaks down the latest CNBC All-America Economic Survey, and Eamon Javers reports on Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent‚Äôs meeting with China‚Äôs Vice Premier amid tense trade talks. Plus, a new partnership with Meta boosts Ray-Ban maker EssilorLuxottica‚Äôs sales by nearly 12%.

In this episode:
Steve Liesman, @steveliesman
Eamon Javers, @eamonjavers
Leslie Picker, @LesliePicker
Joe Kernen, @JoeSquawk 
Becky Quick, @BeckyQuick
Cameron Costa, @CameronCostaNY

sample.title: Trump and Zelensky discuss Tomahawk missiles in US meeting | BBC News
sample.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has arrived to the White House for his meeting with US President Donald Trump.
 
Ukraine is pushing for the US to provide Tomahawk missiles capable of striking targets nearly 2,000km (1,200 miles) away.
 
"We'll be talking about that," Trump said. "It's an escalation, but we'll be talking about it."
 
It comes as Trump has agreed to meet Russian President Putin in Hungary, with fresh talks between the leaders' advisers planned for as early as next week.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

sample.title: Does Trump have enough Tomahawk missiles to help Ukraine? | BBC Ukrainecast
sample.description:
As Volodymyr Zelensky prepares to make his latest pitch to Donald Trump at the White House on Friday, the US is yet to announce a decision on the delivery of long range Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine. Could Washington have given the green light behind the scenes already? Are Ukrainian claims of frontline counteroffensives being exaggerated? And which side is coming out on top when it comes to drone technology?

To answer your questions, Lucy is joined by BBC Verify‚Äôs Olga Robinson and Mikey Kay from The Security Brief on the BBC news channel. The team also discuss Russian attacks on energy infrastructure, Nato military exercises and Halloween celebrations in Ukraine.

Zelensky prepares to meet Trump at White House | BBC News
sample.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky is about to have his third visit to the White House since US President Donald Trump returned to the presidency in January.
 
He is expected to ask for long-range Tomahawk missiles that can strike deep into Russian territory.
 
Trump earlier signalled he might be willing to give Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine, but after speaking to Vladimir Putin yesterday said: "We need them too... so I don't know what we can do about that".
